security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill file (SKILL.md) containing examples of legitimate GitHub CLI operations for multi-repository coordination. The static analyzer flagged documentation examples as code execution patterns. All command invocations use hardcoded GitHub CLI (gh) commands with string literals, not user input. No malicious patterns, credential exfiltration, or harmful operations present. The skill describes DevOps automation workflows using standard tools.

content.value_statement: Managing multiple GitHub repositories manually is complex and error-prone. This skill uses AI swarm orchestration to synchronize packages, align versions, and coordinate changes across all your repositories automatically.
actual_capabilities: Coordinate changes across multiple GitHub repositories simultaneously
Synchronize package versions and dependencies across repositories
Analyze and optimize repository architecture structure
Create standardized templates for new repositories
Deploy security patches across all repositories
Manage cross-repository pull requests and issues
limitations: Requires GitHub CLI (gh) and ruv-swarm MCP server installed
Requires authentication and appropriate permissions for target repositories
Does not handle merge conflicts or complex rebasing scenarios
Limited to repositories accessible via GitHub API

use_cases.title: Deploy organization-wide updates
use_cases.description: Push security patches, dependency updates, or policy changes to all repositories in your organization with one command.

use_cases.title: Maintain repository architecture
use_cases.description: Standardize structure, create templates, and ensure consistency across multiple microservices or packages.

use_cases.title: Coordinate cross-repo dependencies
use_cases.description: Manage shared libraries, align API contracts, and synchronize documentation across interconnected repositories.

prompt_templates.title: List repositories
prompt_templates.prompt: Use github-multi-repo to list all TypeScript repositories in my organization and analyze their dependencies.

prompt_templates.title: Sync packages
prompt_templates.prompt: Use github-multi-repo to synchronize package versions between claude-code-flow and ruv-swarm packages.

prompt_templates.title: Create template
prompt_templates.prompt: Use github-multi-repo to create a standardized project template with CLAUDE.md, package.json, and GitHub workflows.

prompt_templates.title: Security updates
prompt_templates.prompt: Use github-multi-repo to scan all repositories for vulnerabilities and create pull requests with security fixes.

output: Updated TypeScript from 4.x to 5.0.0 in all repositories
Created 5 pull requests with labels 'dependencies' and 'TypeScript update'

output_examples.input: Use github-multi-repo to create a standardized template for new projects.
output: Added CLAUDE.md, package.json, and GitHub workflow files
Template is now available for team use

output_examples.input: Use github-multi-repo to run security audits across all organization repositories.
output: Created pull requests with npm audit fixes for each affected repository

best_practices: Use hierarchical topology for monorepo-style coordination and mesh topology for loosely coupled repositories
Test changes in a single repository before rolling out to all repositories
Enable tracking issues to monitor progress of organization-wide updates
anti_patterns: Running synchronized updates without first verifying changes in a test repository
Using strong consistency mode for documentation updates where eventual consistency is sufficient
Skipping the creation of tracking issues for multi-repository changes

faq.question: What permissions does this skill need?
faq.answer: Requires GitHub CLI with authentication and ruv-swarm MCP server. Needs repo scope for repository access.

faq.question: How many repositories can it handle?
faq.answer: Tested with up to 100 repositories. Performance depends on network latency and GitHub API rate limits.

faq.question: Does it work with private repositories?
faq.answer: Yes, as long as the GitHub CLI is authenticated and has access to the private repositories.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All operations use GitHub API and local tools. No data is sent to third-party services beyond GitHub.

faq.question: What if a repository update fails?
faq.answer: The skill reports failures and can create tracking issues. Each repository is processed independently.

faq.question: How is this different from GitHub Actions?
faq.answer: This skill orchestrates changes at the source level using AI agents, while GitHub Actions runs CI/CD pipelines per repository.
